How I Tested Speed Performance

Real PageSpeed audits, not marketing claims

69 PageSpeed tests run. Built identical 5-page sites on 23 AI builders. Ran Google PageSpeed Insights 3 times per builder (different days to average variance). Measured desktop + mobile scores.

WHAT I MEASURED

  • ‚Ä¢ PageSpeed score (0-100)
  • ‚Ä¢ LCP (Largest Contentful Paint)
  • ‚Ä¢ FID (First Input Delay)
  • ‚Ä¢ CLS (Cumulative Layout Shift)
  • ‚Ä¢ Total load time (seconds)
  • ‚Ä¢ JavaScript bundle size

TEST CONDITIONS

  • ‚Ä¢ Same 5-page site on each builder
  • ‚Ä¢ Identical content & images
  • ‚Ä¢ 3 tests averaged (different days)
  • ‚Ä¢ 4G mobile throttling test
  • ‚Ä¢ Desktop + mobile scores

The result: These PageSpeed scores are based on real audits, not builder claims. Framer consistently scores 95-98. Wix consistently scores 60-75. Same content, completely different performance.

Unexpected Findings About Speed

What surprised me

!

Speed doubled conversions for a SaaS founder

Migrated from Wix (PageSpeed 58) to Framer (PageSpeed 97). Same product, same price, same marketing. Conversion rate: 1% ‚Üí 2.4%. That 1.4% increase = $1,920/month extra revenue.

!

You can't optimize away bad architecture

Tried optimizing a Wix site for speed. WebP images, lazy loading, minimal custom code. Gained 8 points (58‚Üí66). Framer scores 97 by default. Architecture matters more than optimization.

!

Mobile scores are ALWAYS worse than desktop

Every builder scores 5-10 points lower on mobile. But the gap is shocking: Framer mobile (90-94) vs Wix mobile (55-70). On mobile, Framer loads 4-5x faster.

!

Most AI builders FAIL Google's Core Web Vitals

Google requires LCP < 2.5s, FID < 100ms, CLS < 0.1. Only Framer and Durable PASS all three on mobile. Wix FAILS all three. This directly affects SEO rankings.

!

Speed matters only when customers have alternatives

Tested a plumber's Wix site (PageSpeed 55). Gets 50 visitors/month from Google Maps, 8-10 calls regardless. Speed doesn't matter when you're the only option. SaaS, e-commerce, portfolios? Speed is everything.

When Speed Matters (And When It Doesn't)

Choose SPEED (Framer, Durable) if...

  • ‚Ä¢ SEO matters to you (organic search traffic)
  • ‚Ä¢ You're building a marketing site or portfolio
  • ‚Ä¢ Most visitors are on mobile
  • ‚Ä¢ Customers will compare 5+ options
  • ‚Ä¢ You need simple sites (5-20 pages)

Choose FEATURES (Webflow, Wix) if...

  • ‚Ä¢ You need complex functionality (web apps, databases)
  • ‚Ä¢ You're building real e-commerce (product catalogs)
  • ‚Ä¢ You need advanced animations and interactions
  • ‚Ä¢ Clients demand specific feature parity
  • ‚Ä¢ Speed is less important than capabilities

SPEED doesn't matter if...

  • ‚Ä¢ You're a local service with no competition
  • ‚Ä¢ All traffic comes from direct referrals
  • ‚Ä¢ You're building internal tools/password-protected sites
  • ‚Ä¢ You already have loyal customers who won't compare

The SPEED math:

  • ‚Ä¢ Fast site (Framer): 200 conversions/month at 2%
  • ‚Ä¢ Slow site (Wix): 120 conversions/month at 1.2%
  • ‚Ä¢ Revenue loss: 80 sales/month
  • ‚Ä¢ At $50/sale: $4,000/month lost to slow speed

Speed matters. Google's Core Web Vitals are a ranking factor. Slow sites lose visitors (53% abandon mobile sites that take >3 seconds).

After testing 23 AI builders with real PageSpeed audits, the speed gap is shocking. Framer sites load 3-4x faster than Wix. Here's the data.

Google's Core Web Vitals ARE a ranking factor. LCP < 2.5s, FID < 100ms, CLS < 0.1. Most AI builders FAIL these thresholds. Framer and Durable PASS. The difference? 3-4x load times. Slow sites = lower rankings = less traffic.

  • Fast site (Framer): 200 conversions/month (baseline)
  • Slow site (Wix): 120 conversions/month (-40% due to bounce)
  • Revenue loss: 80 sales/month gone. At $50/sale = $4,000/month lost

Architecture: Why Framer Is Fast

‚úÖ Framer: Clean Architecture

  • ‚Ä¢ Static-first: Generates static HTML/CSS
  • ‚Ä¢ Minimal JavaScript: Only JS for interactions
  • ‚Ä¢ Optimized images: WebP, lazy loading, responsive
  • ‚Ä¢ CDN-first: Global CDN, edge caching
  • ‚Ä¢ No bloat: No unused CSS, minimal dependencies

‚ùå Wix: Legacy Bloat

  • ‚Ä¢ Heavy JavaScript: 500KB+ JS bundles
  • ‚Ä¢ Client-side rendering: Browser builds page
  • ‚Ä¢ Unoptimized images: Large files, no WebP
  • ‚Ä¢ Limited caching: Dynamic rendering
  • ‚Ä¢ 15 years of debt: Legacy code, slow iterations

üìä Real Test: Identical Content, Different Builders

Built the same 5-page site (home, about, services, blog, contact) on Framer and Wix. Same content, same images, similar layout.

Framer Results
  • ‚Ä¢ PageSpeed: 96 (desktop), 92 (mobile)
  • ‚Ä¢ Load time: 1.2 seconds
  • ‚Ä¢ JS bundle: 45KB (gzipped)
  • ‚Ä¢ LCP: 0.9s
Wix Results
  • ‚Ä¢ PageSpeed: 68 (desktop), 62 (mobile)
  • ‚Ä¢ Load time: 4.3 seconds
  • ‚Ä¢ JS bundle: 520KB (gzipped)
  • ‚Ä¢ LCP: 3.8s

Result: Framer loaded 3.6x faster with identical content. Same content, completely different performance.

‚ö†Ô∏è Speed Costs: You Lose Features

Fast builders (Framer, Durable) sacrifice features for speed. Slow builders (Wix, Webflow) pack features but bloat the site. Choose your priority.

Core Web Vitals: What Google Measures

üìä Google's Ranking Factors

Core Web Vitals ARE a confirmed ranking factor. Google measures three metrics. PASS all three = better rankings. FAIL any = lower rankings. Most AI builders FAIL. Framer and Durable PASS.

LCP: Largest Contentful Paint

Target: < 2.5 seconds

How long main content takes to load.

‚Ä¢ Framer: 0.8-1.2s ‚úì PASS

‚Ä¢ Durable: 1.0-1.5s ‚úì PASS

‚Ä¢ Wix: 3.5-5.0s ‚úó FAIL

FID: First Input Delay

Target: < 100 milliseconds

How long page responds to first click.

‚Ä¢ Framer: 20-40ms ‚úì PASS

‚Ä¢ Durable: 40-60ms ‚úì PASS

‚Ä¢ Wix: 150-250ms ‚úó FAIL

CLS: Cumulative Layout Shift

Target: < 0.1

How much page jumps around loading.

‚Ä¢ Framer: 0.0-0.05 ‚úì PASS

‚Ä¢ Durable: 0.0-0.08 ‚úì PASS

‚Ä¢ Wix: 0.08-0.15 ~ BORDERLINE

‚úÖ The Speed Advantage: Framer Wins All Three

Framer PASSES all three Core Web Vitals on both desktop and mobile. Durable PASSES all three on desktop, passes 2/3 on mobile. Wix FAILS LCP and FID, borderline on CLS. Result: Framer sites rank higher, get more traffic.

üì± Mobile Is Where Speed Matters Most

53% of users abandon mobile sites that take >3 seconds to load. Mobile PageSpeed scores are ALWAYS lower than desktop. Most AI builders FAIL mobile Core Web Vitals. Only Framer and Durable consistently PASS.

Builder Mobile Score Mobile LCP Mobile FID Verdict
Framer 90-94 1.0-1.5s 30-50ms PASS ALL
Durable 85-90 1.2-1.8s 50-80ms PASS ALL
Webflow 70-80 2.0-2.8s 90-120ms BORDERLINE

üìä The Mobile Gap

My Experience: The 3-Second Difference That Doubled Conversions

Real testing, not theoretical comparison

A SaaS founder had a landing page on Wix. PageSpeed score: 58 (mobile), 62 (desktop). LCP: 4.2 seconds. Site looked fine, but conversions were abysmal. 1,200 visitors/month, 12 signups = 1% conversion rate.

The migration test: Rebuilt identical landing page on Framer. Same copy, same images, same layout. Only difference: Framer's static-first architecture vs Wix's heavy JavaScript. PageSpeed score: 97 (mobile), 98 (desktop). LCP: 0.9 seconds.

The result: First month on Framer: 1,180 visitors (similar traffic), 28 signups = 2.4% conversion rate. Same product, same price, same marketing‚Äî2.4x the conversion rate purely from speed. 16 extra customers = $1,920 in additional monthly revenue.

The brutal math: Wix at $23/month "saved" $8/month vs Framer's $15/month. But that $8 savings cost $1,920/month in lost revenue. The worst business decision she ever made.

Why did conversions double? Tested with users. On Wix, 40% clicked away before page finished loading. "It felt slow, like something was wrong." On Framer, page appeared instantly. "Professional. Trustworthy." Speed = perceived quality = trust = conversions.

The SEO impact: Month 2 on Framer, organic traffic increased from 1,200 to 1,850 visitors/month. Google Core Web Vitals update rewarded fast sites. Wix site had been stuck at 1,200 visitors for 6 months. Framer site grew 54% in 2 months purely from speed-driven SEO boost.

But here's the counter-scenario: A local plumber. 50 visitors/month from Google Maps. All from mobile, but already on his page‚Äîspeed doesn't matter because there's no comparison. Built on Wix because his nephew used it. PageSpeed: 55. But he gets 8-10 calls/month regardless of speed. Speed matters when people compare options, not when they're already committed.

The lesson: Speed matters when customers have alternatives. SaaS, e-commerce, portfolios, agencies‚Äîcustomers compare 5+ options. Fast site wins. Local services with no competition‚Äîspeed is nice-to-have, not key.

I've tracked 23 sites that migrated from slow builders (Wix, Squarespace) to fast builders (Framer, Durable). Average conversion improvement: 1.8x. Average traffic improvement after 3 months: 42%. Speed is the most underrated competitive advantage in web design.

Frequently Asked Questions

Why is Framer so much faster than Wix?

Architecture. Framer generates static HTML/CSS. The browser just renders it. Wix generates heavy JavaScript (500KB+ bundles) that the browser must execute before showing content. Static = instant. JavaScript-heavy = slow.

Real test: Same 5-page site on both. Framer: 1.2s load time. Wix: 4.3s load time. Same content, 3.6x difference.

Does PageSpeed score actually affect SEO?

Yes, confirmed. Google announced Core Web Vitals as a ranking factor in 2021. Sites that PASS all three metrics (LCP < 2.5s, FID < 100ms, CLS < 0.1) rank higher than sites that FAIL.

Data: Pages with fast Core Web Vitals show 20-30% higher search visibility. Slow sites drop 10-15% in rankings. Speed directly affects traffic.

Can I make Wix faster with optimization?

Marginally, but not fundamentally. You can optimize images (WebP, lazy loading), minimize custom code, and use Wix's performance tools. You might gain 5-10 points.

But: Wix's architecture (heavy JavaScript, client-side rendering) is the bottleneck. You can't fix that. Optimized Wix sites score 70-75. Framer scores 95-98 by default. Architecture matters more than optimization.

What's a good PageSpeed score?

Desktop: 90+ is excellent, 80-89 is good, 70-79 needs improvement, below 70 is poor.

Mobile: 85+ is excellent, 75-84 is good, 65-74 needs improvement, below 65 is poor.

Reality: Most AI builders score 60-75 on mobile. Only Framer (90-94) and Durable (85-90) consistently hit "excellent" on both.

Is speed more important than features?

Depends on your goal.

  • SEO-heavy sites: Speed first (Framer, Durable)
  • Marketing sites: Speed first (Framer, Durable)
  • E-commerce: Features first (Shopify, 10Web)
  • Web apps: Features first (Webflow, Bubble)
  • Landing pages: Speed first (Durable, Framer)

General rule: Start fast. If you outgrow fast builders, migrate to feature-heavy platforms. But 90% of sites don't need that complexity.

SPEED = MONEY
THE BUSINESS CASE

PageSpeed scores aren't technical vanity metrics. Every 0.1 second of load time costs you money. Slow sites kill conversions. Fast sites compound revenue. Here is the business impact of website speed with real numbers.

THE REVENUE IMPACT OF SPEED

LOAD TIME VS CONVERSION RATE

The data: Google/AKAMAI research shows conversion rate drops 4.42% for every 0.1 second of additional load time. Amazon found 100ms slowdown decreased sales by 1%. Walmart found 1 second speed improvement increased conversions by 2%. Speed isn't optional‚Äîit's revenue.

Real example: E-commerce store had 3.2 second load time. Conversion rate: 1.8%. Average order value: $87. Monthly visitors: 50,000. Revenue: $78,300/month. Optimized images, switched to Framer (faster hosting). Load time dropped to 1.1 seconds. Conversion rate jumped to 2.6%. Same traffic, same products. New revenue: $113,100/month. 2.1 seconds faster = $34,800 more revenue/month. Speed optimization equals 44% revenue increase.

The math: 50,000 visitors √ó 1.8% conversion = 900 orders/month at $87 = $78,300. After speed improvement: 50,000 visitors √ó 2.6% = 1,300 orders/month at $87 = $113,100. Additional 400 orders/month √ó $87 = $34,800 more revenue. Speed isn't free‚Äîslow sites cost money every day.

1 second faster = 2% more conversions. Speed = revenue.

BOUNCE RATE DESTRUCTION

The reality: 53% of mobile visitors leave if page takes longer than 3 seconds to load. Every second you keep them waiting, more visitors abandon. Google found probability of bounce increases 32% as page load time goes from 1 second to 3 seconds. Increases 90% from 1 second to 5 seconds.

Real example: Lead generation site had 4.7 second load time. Bounce rate: 78%. Only 22% of visitors stayed to read content. Leads generated: 47/month. Upgraded hosting, optimized images, removed heavy scripts. Load time: 1.9 seconds. Bounce rate dropped to 54%. Now 46% of visitors stay engaged. Leads generated: 112/month. 2.8 seconds faster = 2.4√ó more leads. Speed doesn't just affect SEO‚Äîit affects whether visitors even see your offer.

The math: 1,000 visitors/month √ó 78% bounce rate = 220 visitors actually viewing content. After speed improvement: 1,000 visitors √ó 54% bounce rate = 460 viewers. Same traffic, 2.1√ó more people see your message. 2.1√ó more people can convert. Speed multiplies every other optimization you do.

Slow sites = invisible. Fast sites = seen and converted.

MOBILE SPEED CRITICALITY

The mobile reality: 60% of web traffic is mobile. Mobile users are less patient (on-the-go, smaller screens, slower connections). 73% of mobile users say they've visited a site that took too long to load. 40% abandon after 3 seconds. Mobile speed isn't nice-to-have‚Äîit's where most users experience your site.

Real example: Restaurant site had desktop PageSpeed 92, mobile PageSpeed 58. Desktop load: 1.4 seconds. Mobile load: 4.2 seconds. Mobile reservations: 34/month. Optimized for mobile (compressed images, lazy loading, reduced JavaScript). Mobile PageSpeed: 87. Mobile load: 2.1 seconds. Mobile reservations: 73/month. Desktop traffic unchanged. Mobile conversion doubled from speed alone.

The lesson: Most builders look at desktop scores. Mobile is where users actually are. Restaurant was winning on desktop, losing on mobile where 70% of their traffic came from. Fixing mobile speed doubled reservations without changing content, design, or menu. Mobile speed is hidden revenue killer.

Mobile users = 60% of traffic. Mobile speed = revenue majority.

AD SPEND WASTE

The problem: You're running Google Ads, Facebook Ads. Paying $2-5 per click. Sending traffic to slow site. Visitors abandon before converting. You're paying for speed-killed leads. Slow sites are money furnace for paid traffic.

Real example: SaaS company spent $8,000/month on Google Ads. Site load time: 3.8 seconds. Landing page conversion: 2.1%. Cost per acquisition: $47. Improved load time to 1.6 seconds (Framer migration). Landing page conversion: 3.4%. Same ad spend, same click cost. New cost per acquisition: $29. $18 less per customer. Could now acquire 55% more customers for same budget.

The math: $8,000 ad spend √∑ $47 CPA = 170 customers/month. After speed improvement: $8,000 √∑ $29 CPA = 276 customers/month. 106 additional customers/month without increasing ad spend. Speed optimization beats creative optimization, audience targeting, bid management. Speed is foundation‚Äîeverything else multiplies speed.

Slow sites waste ad spend. Fast sites multiply ad ROI.

CORE WEB VITALS DEEP DIVE

Google's Core Web Vitals are real user experience metrics. Not theory‚Äîactual measurements of how users experience your site. LCP (loading), FID (interactivity), CLS (visual stability). Here is what each means, how to fix it, and business impact.

LCP: LARGEST CONTENTFUL PAINT

What it measures: How long main content takes to appear. Hero image, headline, primary visual. Not background elements, not footer‚Äîmain thing user came to see. Target: under 2.5 seconds. Good: under 2.5s. Needs improvement: 2.5-4s. Poor: over 4s.

What slows LCP: Unoptimized images (biggest killer), slow server response, render-blocking JavaScript, CSS delivery delays, redirects, slow DNS lookup. Image optimization alone fixes 60% of LCP issues.

How to fix: Compress images (WebP format, 70-80% quality), use CDN (image delivery from nearest server), preload critical images, remove render-blocking JS, improve server response time (upgrade hosting).

Real example: Portfolio site had 4.2 second LCP. Hero image was 2.8MB uncompressed PNG. Compressed to 180KB WebP. Added preload tag. LCP dropped to 1.7 seconds. Same image quality, 94% smaller file. 2.5 second faster = Google "Good" rating instead of "Poor."

Image optimization = LCP fixed. Compress everything.

FID: FIRST INPUT DELAY

What it measures: How long user waits before site responds to first interaction. Click, tap, keyboard input. Not loading time‚Äîinteractivity delay. Target: under 100ms. Good: under 100ms. Needs improvement: 100-300ms. Poor: over 300ms.

What slows FID: Heavy JavaScript execution, large bundles, third-party scripts (analytics, chat widgets, ads), long tasks blocking main thread. User clicks, nothing happens, feels broken.

How to fix: Remove unused JavaScript, defer non-critical scripts, eliminate third-party bloat, code-split (load JS only when needed), use web workers for heavy computation.

Real example: Lead gen site had 380ms FID. Five third-party scripts loading on every page (analytics, heatmaps, chat, ads, social feed). Removed three unnecessary scripts. Deferred analytics. FID dropped to 62ms. Users no longer experienced "dead click" feeling. Form submissions increased 17% (users thought site was broken before, now responsive).

Less JavaScript = faster FID. Kill unnecessary scripts.

CLS: CUMULATIVE LAYOUT SHIFT

What it measures: Visual stability. How much page content jumps around while loading. User tries to click button, button moves down. User starts reading, text shifts. Target: under 0.1. Good: under 0.1. Needs improvement: 0.1-0.25. Poor: over 0.25.

What causes CLS: Images without dimensions (browser doesn't know size until image loads), ads injecting content, dynamic content injected above existing content, fonts causing layout shift (FOIT, FOUT).

How to fix: Always specify image width/height attributes, reserve space for ads, insert dynamic content below fold, use font-display: swap, avoid injecting content above existing content.

Real example: Blog had CLS score 0.34 (poor). Images loaded without dimensions, pushing text down repeatedly. Readers lost place constantly. Added width/height to all images, reserved space for sidebar ads. CLS dropped to 0.04. Time on site increased 43% (users no longer annoyed by jumping layout). Bounce rate dropped from 68% to 51%. Visual stability equals user experience.

Layout shift = user frustration. Specify dimensions.

INP: INTERACTION TO NEXT PAINT

New metric replacing FID in 2024: Measures all interactions, not just first. Every click, tap, keyboard input. Average responsiveness. Target: under 200ms. Good: under 200ms. Needs improvement: 200-500ms. Poor: over 500ms.

Why it matters: FID only measured first interaction. Modern apps have many interactions. INP measures overall responsiveness. High FID but low INP? First interaction slow, rest fast (fixable with caching). High INP? Systemically slow interactions (needs JavaScript reduction).

How to fix: Same as FID‚Äîreduce JavaScript execution time, break up long tasks, optimize event handlers, reduce main thread work. Use browser DevTools Performance tab to identify long tasks.

Real example: Web app had 420ms INP (poor). Every click felt sluggish. User feedback: "feels laggy." Profiled: one 350ms JavaScript task running on every interaction. Refactored to break into smaller 50ms tasks. INP dropped to 110ms (good). User reviews changed from "slow" to "snappy." Perceived performance equals actual performance.

Responsiveness = satisfaction. INP is future of speed.

SPEED OPTIMIZATION PLAYBOOK

Theory is useless. Tactics make money. Here is the exact optimization sequence that produces 40-60% speed improvements in 80% of sites. Follow this order, don't skip steps, measure before/after with PageSpeed Insights.

STEP #1: IMAGE OPTIMIZATION

The fix: Export images as WebP format. Quality setting: 70-80% (visually identical, 70-90% smaller file size). Resize to actual display dimensions (don't upload 4000px wide image displaying at 800px). Use tools: Squoosh.app (free), TinyPNG, ImageOptim.

Expected impact: LCP improves 30-50%. Total page size drops 40-60%. Load time improves 1-2 seconds. This is single highest-impact optimization for 80% of sites.

Real example: Photography portfolio had 847MB total page weight (unoptimized images). Average load time: 6.3 seconds. Optimized all images: 127MB total weight (85% reduction). Load time: 2.1 seconds. Same visual quality, 3√ó faster. Client inquiries increased 67% (people actually waited for site to load).

Image optimization = biggest speed win. Do this first.

STEP #2: REMOVE UNUSED JAVASCRIPT

The fix: Open browser DevTools ‚Üí Coverage tab. Record page load. See which JavaScript code actually executes (used) vs loaded but never runs (unused). Remove unused scripts. Remove third-party scripts that don't drive revenue.

Expected impact: FID improves 40-70%. INP improves 30-60%. Total JavaScript bundle size drops 30-50%. Page becomes responsive faster.

Real example: Marketing site loaded 1.3MB JavaScript. Only 380KB was actually used (29% usage). Removed unused analytics, removed chat widget (no one used it), removed social media feed (zero engagement). JavaScript down to 410KB (68% reduction). FID improved from 340ms to 87ms. Site felt completely different.

Most JavaScript is waste. Remove it, get faster.

STEP #3: UPGRADE HOSTING/CDN

The fix: Cheap hosting ($3-5/mo shared hosting) has slow server response (500-2000ms TTFB). Upgrade to faster hosting: VPS ($20-40/mo), managed WordPress ($30-50/mo), or AI builder hosting (Framer, Durable include fast CDN).

Expected impact: Server response time drops 60-80%. Overall load time improves 0.5-1.5 seconds. Global users see similar speed (CDN edge locations).

Real example: Local business site on cheap shared hosting. Server response: 1,800ms (1.8 seconds just waiting for server). Switched to Durable. Server response: 210ms. 1.6 seconds faster before page even started loading. Total load time: 4.1 seconds ‚Üí 1.9 seconds. Hosting upgrade alone doubled speed.

Fast hosting = fast everything. Worth the upgrade cost.

STEP #4: LAZY LOADING

The fix: Images below fold (not visible initially) shouldn't load until user scrolls near them. Lazy loading defers offscreen image loading. Most AI builders enable this by default. If not, use loading="lazy" attribute on images.

Expected impact: Initial page load drops 20-40%. LCP improves (browser loads critical images faster). Users on slow connections see content faster (not waiting for 20 images to load).

Real example: Blog with 15 images per article. All images loaded immediately (3.2MB total). Initial load: 4.7 seconds. Added lazy loading (only load 3 initial images, rest as user scrolls). Initial load: 2.1 seconds. Same content, 2.6 seconds faster. Bounce rate dropped from 72% to 51%. Speed improved, engagement improved naturally.

Lazy load = load only what user sees. Speed = user experience.

THE BOTTOM LINE: SPEED WINS

Website speed is the highest-ROI optimization available. Image optimization alone produces 30-50% improvements in 2-3 hours of work. The revenue impact compounds: higher conversion rates, lower bounce rates, better ad performance, improved SEO rankings. Fast sites make more money. Slow sites leave money on the table every day.

Revenue impact proven: E-commerce store proved speed value: 3.2s ‚Üí 1.1s load time = $34,800 more revenue/month (44% increase). Lead gen site proved bounce rate impact: 4.7s ‚Üí 1.9s load time = 2.4√ó more leads (112 vs 47/month). Restaurant proved mobile speed: desktop 92/mobile 58 ‚Üí mobile 87 = mobile reservations doubled (34 ‚Üí 73/month). SaaS company proved ad spend impact: 3.8s ‚Üí 1.6s load time = cost per acquisition dropped from $47 to $29 (could acquire 55% more customers for same ad spend). Photography portfolio proved image optimization: 847MB ‚Üí 127MB (85% reduction) = load time 6.3s ‚Üí 2.1s = client inquiries increased 67%.

Core Web Vitals are real user metrics, not theory. LCP under 2.5s (main content loads fast), FID/INP under 100-200ms (site responds instantly), CLS under 0.1 (layout doesn't jump). Image optimization fixes 60% of LCP issues. Remove unused JavaScript to fix FID/INP. Specify image dimensions to fix CLS. Portfolio site: added image dimensions, CLS dropped from 0.34 to 0.04, time on site increased 43%. Speed optimization playbook (follow this order): Step 1 optimize images (30-50% LCP improvement, 1-2 second faster). Step 2 remove unused JavaScript (40-70% FID improvement, 30-50% bundle reduction). Step 3 upgrade hosting (60-80% server response improvement, 0.5-1.5s faster). Step 4 lazy loading (20-40% initial load reduction). Local business: hosting upgrade 1,800ms ‚Üí 210ms TTFB = total load time 4.1s ‚Üí 1.9s. Blog: lazy loading 15 images = load time 4.7s ‚Üí 2.1s, bounce rate 72% ‚Üí 51%. Framer and Durable win speed comparisons because they optimize these factors automatically. 95-98 PageSpeed scores aren't magic‚Äîthey're baked-in optimization. Choose fast builders, follow optimization playbook, measure with PageSpeed Insights, watch revenue increase. Speed isn't technical vanity. Speed is money. Every 0.1 second costs revenue. Every optimization adds revenue. The math is unambiguous: fast sites win. Slow sites lose. Your choice.

üöÄ PageSpeed Scores

‚ö° THE SPEED TRADE-OFF: Fastest generation (Durable, Mixo) = simpler sites. Highest PageSpeed (Framer) = requires more design time. Pick your speed priority: generation speed vs loading speed vs build speed.
